acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 96 hours LC50=5.81mg/L of the crustacea (Mysid Shrimp)) (CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report, 2005).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (dermal route) value of 148mg/kg representing the lower of the two testing data, 148mg/kg and 282 mg/kg (EHC 28, 1983).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the rat LC50 value of 0.54 mg/L (243ppm), calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of vapour)  of 0.47mg/L (4 hours), 1.03mg/L (4 hours) and 1.21mg/L (4 hours) (EU-PAR No.32, 2004), was lower than 90% of the saturated vapor concentration (110,000ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 11 kPa (20degC)  (IPCS, 2001), the substance was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 87mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 93mg/kg, 101mg/kg, 128mg/kg, 82mg/kg, 86mg/kg, 84mg/kg, 72mg/kg, 78mg/kg and 186mg/kg" (EHC 28, 1983).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category R by NTP (2005) and Group 2B by IARC (1999).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since there was rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 96% (Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)) and the bio-accumulation was low (log Kow=0.25 (PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), it was claasified into Not classified.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: No data available; those containing stabilizers are classified into Class 3 and Category 6.1 (UN#1093) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

explosives.rationale: Containing no atom groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flashing point is -1degC (ICSC, 2004) (closed cup flash test) and the boiling point is 77degC; those containing stabilizers are classified into Class 3 and Category 6.1 (UN#1093) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative data on heritable mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests) and germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo (UDS tests on rat spermatocytes), the absence of data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (gene mutation tests on rat spleen T cells), described in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.64 (2003), CICADS 39 (2002) and EU-RAR No.32 (2004).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen. fluorine and chlorine

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the flashing point is 481degC (ICSC,2004)

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of organ and skeletal malformations in offspring at dosing levels toxic to dams in rat teratogenicity tests, described in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No. 64 (2003).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though containing unsaturated bonds. Those containing stabilizers are classified into Class 3 and Category 6.1 (UN#1093) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the following description by DuPont (1975) on serious eye damage/eye irritation among several testing data in EU-RAR No.32, 2004: "In unwashed eyes, moderate corneal opacity, moderate iritis, severe conjunctival irritation and corneal opacity associated with vascularization observed even after 21 days from exposure. In washed eyes, mild temporary corneal opacity, moderate iris congestion, moderate conjunctival irritation, recovery observed within 3 days from exposure."

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of erythema and edema and an average Draize score of 3.6 obtained in rabbit skin primary irritation tests (EU-RAR No.32, 2004), although no data are available for applications of less than 4 hours.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Based on positive results in guinea pig maximization tests (CICAD, 39 2002).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (nervous system, respiratory system, blood system, testis, kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (nervous system, respiratory system, blood system, testis, kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "central nervous system symptoms including anxiety, headache and nervous breakdown" (CERI Hazard Data 96-3, 1997), "pain in the eyes, nose, throat and respiratory tract" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No. 64, 2003) and "decreases in hemoglobin levels and red and white blood cell counts, immunosuppression" (EU-RAR No.32, 2004) and the evidence from animal studies including "a decrease in sperm count, a decrease in physical capabilities, hyaline cast formation in renal collecting tubules, subacute bronchial pneumonia, focal necrosis in the liver, focal gliosis in the brain and cellular infiltration around the blood vessels" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No. 64, 2003). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (nervous system, liver),
Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation, narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (nervous system, liver)
May cause drowsiness or dizziness (respiratory tract irritation, narcotic effects)
May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation, narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "mild jaundice and spasm" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No. 64, 2003), "effects on the central nervous system and the liver" (CICAD 39, 2002) and "eye, nasal and respiratory irritation, spasm, loss of consciousness and asphyxia" (NICNAS, 2000), with some of the effects on the nervous systems being temporal and reversible (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No. 64, 2003).
